Award.AwardTitle: First Passage Percolation and Related Models
Award.AbstractNarration: The workshop First-Passage Percolation and Related Models will take place at the International Center for Theoretical Sciences in Bangalore, India, July 27-Aug 14, 2020. This workshop will be devoted to presenting the latest research progress on the first-passage percolation (FPP), a probabilistic model of random growth, and closely related models. This is currently an active research area in contemporary probability theory and has important connections to statistical physics. Part of the workshop will be devoted to training graduate students and early career researchers in those topics. This award will provide travel support for the US based participants in the workshop.<br/><br/><br/>In two dimensions, FPP is a model that is conjecturally in the KPZ universality class, which consists of several models describing surface growth processes. Models in the KPZ class are intimately related with random matrix theory, asymptotic representation theory and number theory. FPP and related models have also been studied by physicists as a model for polymers in a random medium or as model of magnetic interfaces, and by biologists as the Eden model of bacterial growth. Much progress has been made on a class of these relatives which are in some senses "exactly solvable" by the methods of integrable probability. However, even at the physics level of heuristic, these models are poorly understood outside of solvable special cases; for instance, there are hardly any results for dimensions larger than 2. Unlike other conferences on FPP-type models, the ICTS workshop will emphasize methods outside of the integrable or exactly solvable framework. By focusing on techniques beyond exact solvability, the workshop will unify participants around solving fundamental problems of interest to the broader scientific community. The workshop website is maintained at https://www.icts.res.in/program/FPP2020.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award covered travel and some organizational expenses for a three-week workshop called "First-passage percolation and related models". First-passage percolation is a model that describes percolation of fluid through a porous medium, the spread of disease, and the growth of crystals. The statistical behavior of this model has deep, mysterious connections to diverse fields like the zeros of the Riemann zeta function, random matrix theory, and representation theory.

The previous workshop of this kind was held in AIM in 2015. It produced a list of open problems that drove much of this research in first-passage percolation for several years. The 2023 workshop at ICTS was a follow-up to that workshop, and provided an opportunity for researchers to report on progress on the fundamental problems in the field. There were 19 invited speakers, and a total of 28 talks.

The workshop was held at a new institute called the International Center for Theoretical Sciences (ICTS) in Bengaluru, India. ICTS is supported by the Indian government and several private sources like the Airbus Foundation, the Simons Foundation, and the Infosys Science Foundation. The program attracted 93 participants from Asia, Europe and the Americas, many of whom were underrepresented minorities.

The program had a significant pedagogical component. The first-week of the program consisted of 4 mini-courses that introduced the field of first-passage percolation to graduate students, postdoctoral scholars and junior researchers. The next two weeks formed the research component of the workshop, where we organized several working groups. The conference participants identified several important problems in first-passage percolation, and formed a consensus on the medium-term future of the field. The groups were led by senior researchers, and junior participants were assigned to these groups based on their interests. For many, it was their first taste of international level research, and the PIs received a lot of positive feedback. Several international collaborations resulted from these working groups, and some of them have either already produced publishable research.

The workshop was originally scheduled to be held in 2021. The pandemic hit, and we were forced to postpone it by two years. In fact, the travel restrictions in India were only eased in May 2023. The PIs faced significant organizational hurdles, and the participants faced visa and travel difficulties. Several participants were only able to participate in hybrid mode. However, with the help of ICTS, we were able to develop innovative workarounds to these difficulties.

To summarize, the workshop provided new opportunities for career development and training of junior researchers, both by providing lecture courses and direct mentorship while working on research problems. The course recordings have been professionally edited and made available to the public. New international collaborations were formed through the workshop's research working groups, and these have already yielded preprints. Finally, the state of the field was surveyed, and a new consensus formed on future directions, for the first time since the 2015 AIM workshop in the area.
